note.p: Birth: Whitelee or Whittle, Lancashire, England (08 February 1617)

Career: Clerk under Dr Burghill, Chancellor of Durham; Mathematical Tutor to the Duke of York (1647); set up as a teacher of mathematics in London but failed to get pupils; under the patronage of Giles Strangeways (FRS 1673), became Surveyor for the draining of the Fens (1649); Surveyor of Tangier (1663); Surveyor-General of the Ordnance; invited John Flamsteed (FRS 1677) to London; Governor of Christ's Hospital; instrumental in the foundation of the Royal Greenwich Observatory and the Mathematical School at Christ's Hospital; died suddenly while travelling from Portsmouth to London; buried with a 62-gun salute; collected a splendid library of scientific works in many languages which was sold at auction after his death
Sources: Bulloch's Roll; DNB; Hunter; Aubrey

References: A J Meadows, 'John Flamsteed, Our Astronomical Observator', review of The Correspondence of John Flamsteed, First Astronomer Royal. Volume I (1666-1682), ed. Eric G Forbes et al, in NR 1996 vol 50 pp 250-253
Marie Boas Hall, 'Surveyor of the Restoration', review of Frances Willmoth, Sir Jonas Moore: Practical Mathematics and Restoration Science in NR 1994 vol 48 pp 153-154
Sir Alan Cook, 'Halley the Londoner' in NR 1993 vol 47 pp 163-177
